articles.title: A post from The Modern Ferret

articles.description:
PHOENIX ‚Äî The Phoenix Zoo gave names to four of its new 21 endangered black-footed ferret kits through voting from Valley residents online.
With over 2,100 votes, the names selected in a landslide were Maple, Acacia, Cedar and Willow, according to a press release.
The Phoenix Zoo is one of six zoos worldwide that breeds black-footed ferrets, one of the most endangered North American species, that ultimately get released back into the wild. ‚ÄúWe are thrilled to have another successful black-footed ferret breeding season and excited for these little kits to grow up and contribute to the recovery of their species,‚Äù Director of Conservation and Science at the Phoenix Zoo. Dr. Tara Harris said.
The zoo has produced over 500 black-footed ferrets in the 30 years that it has been breeding the animals. In 2021, 13 ferrets were released back into the wild in Colorado.
The kits live in specially designed den boxes with their mothers, according to the release,

 Have a story idea or tip? Pass it along to the KTAR News team here.
articles.title: Phoenix Zoo gives names to 4 newborn ferret kits after online contest - KTAR.com

articles.description: Don't let your new pair of ferrets loose in the NewsChannel 21 newsroom. We found out...the hard way! These ferret brothers are cute, loving, curious and must get a loving forever home! They're waiting at the Humane Society of Central Oregon.
articles.title: Pet Pals: Ferrets take over the studio - KTVZ

articles.description: AUSTINTOWN, Ohio (WKBN) ‚Äì A neglected dog and five ferrets are safe after being rescued by an Animal Charity humane agent Thursday. ‚ÄúSomeone left them there intentionally. Tyson is extremely underweight. He is starved, almost to death,‚Äù said Jane MacMurchy, operations director at Animal Charity. Tyson weighed only 46 pounds. He was found in an abandoned Austintown apartment, collapsed in a bathroom, unable to stand, according to an Animal Charity Facebook post.  ‚ÄúThis wasn‚Äôt just a situation where maybe somebody left their animal with somebody else to take care of, you know it was very clear that they were intentionally abandoned and left to starve,‚Äù MacMurchy said. MacMurchy says Tyson was cached with urine and feces, because he couldn‚Äôt stand up to use the bathroom. She said the ferrets were dehydrated and lethargic. ‚ÄúIt took a village to save Tyson and five ferrets seemingly left to die in an apartment yesterday,‚Äù the post stated. Animal Charity did not have a vet on staff yesterday so they called Friends Of Fido MCDP and Tyson was rushed to a local vet clinic for emergency care. Tyson was given lifesaving fluids and started on small meals to slowly reintroduce his body to food. He was also given a bath to remove the caked-on feces and urine.  The ferrets were given lifesaving fluids and a slow introduction to food as well. MacMurchy says they will be pressing criminal charges against the owner, which may include animal cruelty and prohibitions concerning animals. ‚ÄúThe first step is the probable cause hearing, then the next step is to pursue criminal charges,‚Äù she said. Both Tyson and the ferrets are doing well and in the care of Animal Charity. Copyright 2022 Nexstar Media Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.
articles.title: Emaciated dog, 5 ferrets rescued by Animal Charity - WKBN.com

articles.description: The Arizona Center for Nature Conservation/Phoenix Zoo welcomed five more litters of the highly-endangered black-footed ferrets this May and June at its Elaine V. Johnson Conservation Center.¬†There are 21 baby ferrets, or kits, in all born to mothers Akoya, Roseanne, Vermillion, Lady Mary and Canneles, and some will be identified as candidates to be released into the wild.¬†According to Tara Harris, the director of conservation and science for the Phoenix Zoo who oversees its breeding and recovery programs, there are only a few hundred of the animals living in the wild today.¬†Black-footed ferrets are one of the most endangered animals in North America and were actually thought to be extinct, though they were rediscovered in 1981 in Wyoming, according to the Black-footed Ferret Connection. T‚Ä¶
articles.title: Phoenix Zoo welcomes ferret kits, asks for help naming them - The Arizona Republic

articles.description: Ti Gong   Deng Yingya became fascinated by angora ferrets after seeing them in online videos, so she bought one from a pet shop in Putuo District and named it Kai Kai.Bred at a Scandinavian facility, the mammal has a face similar to that of a hamster and is 30-50 centimeters long. Owners praise the animals as "clean as cats and friendly as dogs." With training, ferrets can even learn to do a few tricks."I have raised both cats and dogs, and yes, my lovely Kai Kai is as cute as expected," the marketing specialist said of her new pet.The angora is a relatively new breed of ferret, in existence for about three decades.Deng bought her ferret from a shop at the Lanling Flower & Bird Market ‚Äì the largest venue selling pets and ornamental plants in Shanghai.The shop, operated by Ding Ning, is‚Ä¶
articles.title: Niche pets can be oh so cute, but your home environment may kill them - SHINE

articles.description: Reddit user Gisgiii posed a question to the AskReddit subforum ‚ÄúWhat is a subtle sign that someone is really intelligent?‚Äù and the answers painted a clear picture of how smart people behave. They tend to be great communicators who understand their audience and are more concerned with getting things right than being right.Here are 18 of the best answers."They draw wisdom from multiple sources. Wait but that might be more wise than intelligent... But I guess those two tend to be seen together a lot," ‚Äî Puzzlehead-Engineer"They can switch up the way they talk to match the person they're talking to without sounding condescending. They listen to how others learn and explain it in that person's language of understanding," ‚Äî Wynonna99"I used to work with a doctor - Tom Howard - and the day I real‚Ä¶

articles.description:
Come One, Come All to the Greatest Ferret Show On Earth!The Greater Chicago Ferret Association returns to DuPage County Fairgrounds in Wheaton this year for The Greatest Ferret Show on Earth, The GCFA's largest fundraiser, on Saturday, October 8th from 9 a.m. until 5 p.m. All proceeds benefit the 300+ ferrets that come through the shelter door each year waiting for their forever home.
Thank You Sponsors!
We couldn't put on The Greatest Ferret Show on Earth without the support of our sponsors!
Fuzzy Stuff, Hooman Stuff, & Prizes You'll Love
This year promises to be the best show yet, complete with 
the spectacular GCFA raffle table featuring numerous sought-after prizes
 including jewelry, pet accessories and products. Over 20 vendors will 
also attend, including those that specializing in small animals, as well
 as pet supplies.
This event is your one stop shop for custom cages, quality 
hand-made bedding, ferret food, indoor and outdoor decorations, toys and
 clothing for ferrents!  A fun event for the whole family- kids will 
love the Ferret Costume Contest, just in time for Halloween!
Additionally, Matty Giuliano, author of the children's book "My 
Name is Musky!" will be doing a book signing and meet & greet!
	All ferrets entering the show hall must meet registration requirements whether being shown or not. Please visit our show website for details.
If you would like to be a vendor or to advertise in our show book, click here for contact information.
We desperately need volunteers to make our show welcoming and run
 efficiently. We need show stewards, runners, fill-ins for breaks and 
raffle help. Whether you are available for 4 hours or all-day, 
	here is the link to register.
For more information please visit our show website.
You are also invited to join our Facebook group for all the latest news.
articles.title: Greatest Ferret Show on Earth - 10/8/2022

articles.description:
Annual GCFA Holiday PartyWhen: Saturday, December 3, 2022 | 11 - 4pmWhere: 15052 Archer Ave, Lockport, IL 60441The
 GCFA hosts this fun filled party to thank all of our members, friends 
and all of our volunteers for everything you do throughout the year.  
The shelter exists because of the generosity of each and every one of 
you. All your ferrets are invited and we will have some fun, 
ferret games.  Tube races, paper bag escape, and kissing contest.  Last 
but not least, start thinking about how to dress your ferret for our 
costume contest!!  Don‚Äôt forget about the ‚ÄúUGLY SWEATER CONTEST‚Äù
 for the humans.  You don‚Äôt have to participate, but if you have an ugly
 sweater please wear it and you may win!!There will be a pot 
luck luncheon, so please bring your favorite, yummy food items to share.
  GCFA will supply soda, water and coffee.There will also be 
ferrety items for your shopping pleasure.  You know you have to have 
something under the tree for your ferrets!!!!We will also have the GCFA‚Äôs fabulous raffle of wonderful ferret items, plus some great items for us humans too.   Please remember, your ferrets must be current on distemper vaccine to attend the party.
articles.title: GCFA Holiday Party- Saturday, 12-3-2022
